and January 1, 1937 the total number of educational station licenses in
the United States had dropped from 202 to 37. Several of these, in des¬
perate efforts to survive, had made compromises which greatly clouded
the definition of educational broadcasting * Many were operating on a
commercial or semi-commercial basis. The membership of the AGUES
numbered only 20 stations in 1933. By 1944 membership in the Associa¬
tion (whose name was changed in 1934 to the NAEB) had risen to only 23
stations.
In the lata 1930*s the NAEB, working with the United States
Office of Education, filed requests for the reservation of both AM and FM
radio frequencies for education in order to protect educational services
against commercial onslaughts, which they were demonstrably unable to
withstand, with the hope of preserving these electronic media as resources
of American education. In its reservations of 1938 and 1940 the Federal
Communications Commission finally set aside five channels in the ultra-
high radio band (later designated as FM) for education. No reservations
were granted for education in AM radio (the "standard*9 radio service).
The NAEB is still continuing its efforts, with other responsible educational
groups, to secure such reservations for education, for all available elec¬
tronic media should, we feel, be as available to education as to commerce.
